issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the collection type for Farm.animals: the UML diagram and several places refer to animals as a List<Animal>, while the textual instructions under "Part 3" explicitly require the aggregation to be realized using a Set implemented with a HashSet and initialized in the no-arg constructor. Students will be unsure whether they must implement a List (as shown in the UML) or a Set/HashSet (as specified in the text), which affects the field type, constructor, getter/setter signatures, and behavior (uniqueness/no-duplicates).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement consistent. Either (A) update the UML and any references that show List<Animal> to use Set<Animal> (and, optionally, show/mention HashSet in implementation notes), or (B) change the textual instructions to require a List/ArrayList and remove the uniqueness/HashSet requirement. Prefer (A) to preserve the stated requirement that the farm holds unique animals without duplicates: change the UML attribute to animals: Set<Animal> and any wording that references a List to reference a Set/HashSet.

issues.description: The solution implementation of Farm uses a List/ArrayList for the animals field and related methods, while the problem text requires the Farm aggregation to be a Set implemented with a HashSet (to ensure uniqueness). This is a cross-artifact structural mismatch: the reference solution does not implement the explicitly required collection type, which will confuse students and may cause tests that expect a Set/HashSet or uniqueness behavior to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem requirements by changing Farm to use a Set<Animal> and a HashSet implementation: (1) change the field type to private Set<Animal> animals; (2) import java.util.Set and java.util.HashSet; (3) initialize animals = new HashSet<>(); (4) change getter/setter signatures to use Set<Animal>; (5) ensure addAnimal calls animals.add(animal) (HashSet will enforce uniqueness). If the intended design was actually to use a List, update the problem statement (as suggested in the first fix) so the solution and specification match.

issues.description: The collection type used to hold animals in Farm is inconsistent across artifacts. The UML in the problem statement declares the attribute as List<Animal>, the textual requirements explicitly instruct students to use a Set implemented with a HashSet and initialize it in the no-arg constructor, while the solution implementation uses a List backed by ArrayList. This mismatch (List vs Set/HashSet) creates ambiguity for students about which data structure to implement and why, and may lead to unnecessary confusion or incorrect implementations relative to the written instructions or tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection choice consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement/UML to require a List/ArrayList throughout (and change the textual instruction about HashSet), or (B) change the solution and any template skeleton to use Set<Animal> with a HashSet initialization in the no-arg constructor (private Set<Animal> animals; this.animals = new HashSet<>();), and update the UML to show Set<Animal>. Prefer aligning to the explicit textual requirement (use Set/HashSet) if the intention is to enforce uniqueness of animals.
